images.copyright: Aerial view of a sandy beach in Mangaluru, Karnataka (© Amith Nag Photography/Moment/Getty Images)
images.title: A shore thing in Mangaluru
images.caption: Mangalore, Karnataka
images.desc: Mangaluru sits on India's western coast, facing the Arabian Sea, with a shoreline defined by long beaches, river mouths and an active maritime presence. The city's location has shaped its identity for centuries, linking it to coastal trade, fishing activity, and the wider routes of the Konkan. Its seafront is less of an attraction and more a fundamental part of how Mangaluru has grown, connecting land, water and people in a way that feels instinctive to the region.

og.title: Mangalore, Karnataka
og.desc: Mangaluru sits on India's western coast, facing the Arabian Sea, with a shoreline defined by long beaches, river mouths and an active…

images.copyright: Plate ice along Lake Superior, Grand Marais, Minnesota, United States (© wanderluster/Getty Images)
images.title: Shards of winter
images.caption: Plate ice along Lake Superior, Minnesota, United States
images.desc: When winter tightens its grip on Lake Superior in Minnesota, United States, the shoreline transforms into a landscape of tilted, glass-like shards known as plate ice. Thin sheets fracture under shifting temperatures, then drift and stack as the wind presses them toward land. The result is a field of translucent blues and silvers, catching the light at sharp angles and making the water's edge appear sculpted rather than frozen.

og.title: Plate ice along Lake Superior, Minnesota, United States
og.desc: When winter tightens its grip on Lake Superior in Minnesota, United States, the shoreline transforms into a landscape of tilted, glass-like…

images.copyright: Salisbury Cathedral, Wiltshire, England (© Julian Elliott Photography/Getty Images)
images.title: Unboxed traditions
images.caption: Boxing Day
images.desc: In England there is a day called Boxing Day that follows Christmas and its charm lies in how quietly it arrives. No countdowns. No frantic unwrapping. Just a pause on 26 December after the festive rush for families and friends alike. The tradition began in Victorian Britain when households prepared Christmas boxes for workers and tradespeople offering coins or essentials as gestures of thanks. Churches opened their alms boxes as well turning the day into one of small thoughtful giving and shared goodwill.

og.title: Boxing Day
og.desc: In England there is a day called Boxing Day that follows Christmas and its charm lies in how quietly it arrives. No countdowns. No frantic…

images.copyright: Snow globes at a Christmas market in Heidelberg, Germany (© George Pachantouris/Getty Images)
images.title: Miniature worlds, infinite wonder
images.caption: Merry Christmas!
images.desc: Beneath Heidelberg's winter sky in Germany, stalls sparkle with snow globes, each capturing the spirit of the season in a miniature world. Today, Christmas—a Christian celebration of faith, light and togetherness—invites us to welcome warmth and joy into the coldest days of the year. Across continents, candles glow on windowsills and garlands twine through homes and streets. Evergreen trees stand adorned, their branches heavy with ornaments and gifts waiting quietly beneath.

og.title: Merry Christmas!
og.desc: Beneath Heidelberg's winter sky in Germany, stalls sparkle with snow globes, each capturing the spirit of the season in a miniature world…

images.copyright: Snowy chapel with Christmas tree in the Bavarian Alps, Germany (© mauritius images GmbH/Alamy)
images.title: Traditions that travel
images.caption: Christmas Eve
images.desc: As Christmas Eve arrives, millions embrace customs that connect us to our roots—or introduce us to entirely new cultures. In snowy regions like the Bavarian Alps in Germany—a frost-kissed landscape seen in today's image—festive lights glow against winter's chill. Elsewhere, the sun blazes brightly: think of the Caribbean, Australia, or Brazil, where Christmas often means golden beaches instead of frosty mornings.

og.title: Christmas Eve
og.desc: As Christmas Eve arrives, millions embrace customs that connect us to our roots—or introduce us to entirely new cultures. In snowy regions…

images.copyright: Reindeer during winter snowfall, Lapland, Finland (© Roberto Moiola/Getty Images)
images.title: Where holiday magic runs on hooves
images.caption: Reindeer, Lapland, Finland
images.desc: Few creatures evoke the magic of the holidays quite like the reindeer. Also known as caribou, they are the spirit animals of Christmas lovers—and they rock it. Sturdy and sure-footed, they've been pulling Santa's sleigh ever since Clement Clarke Moore cast them in the role in his 1823 poem 'A Visit from Saint Nicholas.' And they were born for it. Their hooves shrink in winter to expose a gripping rim, then expand in warmer months for better traction. Still not impressed? Consider this: reindeer don't have an internal clock. Instead, their melatonin—the hormone that regulates sleep—adjusts to light and darkness, helping them stay awake through endless nights of gift delivery.
images.bsTitle: Where holiday magic runs on hooves

og.title: Reindeer, Lapland, Finland
og.desc: Few creatures evoke the magic of the holidays quite like the reindeer. Also known as caribou, they are the spirit animals of Christmas…

images.copyright: 'The Nutcracker' performed by the Turkish State Opera and Ballet in Ankara, Türkiye (© Anadolu/Getty Images)
images.title: From Hoffmann's pages to global stages
images.caption: 'The Nutcracker' performed by the Turkish State Opera and Ballet in Türkiye
images.desc: As Christmas approaches, each sunset gives way to a glow of festive lights, bringing a touch of wonder and preparing us for the holiday season. One of the world's most beloved stage works, 'The Nutcracker,' is rooted in this very sense of magic. The story unfolds on Christmas Eve, in the midst of holiday cheer, when Clara receives a nutcracker as a gift. As night falls and the household drifts into sleep, the little girl and her nutcracker embark on a fantastical journey—battling the Mouse King and wandering through the Land of Sweets. Among its most famous moments is the dance of the Sugar Plum Fairy—the ruler of the Land of Sweets—accompanied by music that has become iconic. Tchaikovsky composed these enchanting melodies for the celesta, an instrument often called the bell-piano. Based on the book 'The Nutcracker and the Mouse King' by E.T.A.
images.bsTitle: From Hoffmann's pages to global stages

images.copyright: Dawn light through frosty trees, Sweden (© Schon/Getty Images)
images.title: Birth of the new sun
images.caption: Winter solstice
images.desc: Ever felt as if the night just wouldn't end? That's the winter solstice working its magic. It is the shortest day and longest night of the year in the Northern Hemisphere, occurring around December 21 or 22. In the Southern Hemisphere, the same happens around June 21 or 22. It marks the moment when one of Earth's poles tilts farthest from the sun. From that instant, daylight slowly begins to lengthen again.
